text: Patient: Not at all. Not at all. Doctor: Thanks for fixing your hepatitis. I’m real, thank you, I’m glad that it’s done. Patient: Got that did. Doctor: Dr. J____ treated you right. Patient: I’ve got a - I’ve got my uh colonoscopy. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I got that did. Doctor: Yep. See slowly we’re fixing you up. Patient: Yeah I’ll be good in no time. Okay. (laughs) Doctor: The only thing not behaving is your prostate number though. Patient: That’s because I didn’t get it. After three months it was four and a half. That’s what happened. Doctor: Yeah. You still shouldn’t be sort of rising.

text: Family Member: Oh, they’re taping us now? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Oh, I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. We’re getting his whole lunch live right now in color Doctor: Well I’m glad you’re feeling a little better. Just you know take your time. We’re okay. We’ll see what that PSA shows. I’m glad we straightened out the whole pill action and everything else. Patient: Yeah. That’s all been handled. Doctor: But you know with the XTANDI it makes you tired. Then sometimes you don’t really want to eat. And it’s hard, you’re such a tough diabetic to begin with, minus the pills. You being on it like you are is probably the best thing for you to stay on it because you might bottom out a lot faster than normal. Okay? Patient: Okay. Family Member: And he has been going low a little bit now and then. Doctor: Yeah. Well because you’re so used to being very high. Patient: Well, you know, I-no I’m not used to being very high. Doctor: Well, yeah, except when you come here you’re high.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign. Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove.

Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove.

text: Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. text: Family Member: Ohhhh. Doctor: - outside that prostate gland. So it’s raising in my mind a good dilemma whether to do something for it or not. Patient: Uh huh. Okay. Doctor: And since you don’t have disease; you know if you had disease in twenty spots which is most people in this situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - with this kind of cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We would say forget why are we even bothering to putting you in harm’s way or side effects way – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - by trying to just take care of the prostate when everything else is out there. Patient: Right.

text: Family Member: What does cure mean? Doctor: Cure means that once we’re done all this therapy, the cancer is gone forever. Family Member: So, so yeah - Doctor: Which we won’t know for five, ten years. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately you know you’re a survivor now. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay and I did mention to you that your testosterone is also going up. Patient: Right. Doctor: However, I think given the fact that you’re feeling relatively well. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Except for that slight increase in fatigue, perhaps, and given that the PSA level is still very low, and I can’t imagine that a PSA of zero point five comes high to you or your body or you know increase the risk of this prostate cancer causing you know either side effects or um you know even death because it’s still quite low. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: My approach would be as we discussed last time to wait until that PSA level goes above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if we don’t. That may not happen for three months; it may not happen for six months. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace it will probably happen – have the PSA will reach one point zero in the next year. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: I know. Doctor: No, you don’t, no. Patient: I don’t need the shot? Doctor: No. Patient: Good. Okay, I’ll just let it go. I appreciate the time that you spend. Doctor: Oh, of course. I just wanted to wrap everything, yeah, because, you know, this always happens in medicine, right, we have one path and we’re like we’re going this way, it’s like no, everybody to the left, everybody to the left. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
